Package edu.bu.pas.pokemon.core

Class Battle

java.lang.Object
edu.bu.pas.pokemon.core.Battle
public class Battle extends Object
A class representing a pokemon battle between two Teams of Pokemon controlled by two separate Agents. This class contains the turn logic for gen-1 Pokemon.
In this implementation of Pokemon, a turn is defined no differently than existing Pokemon rules. Each turn obeys the same state machine:
  1. post turn conditions are applied. At the moment this does nothing, but it would be a place for future pokemon generation logic to occur (such as terrain changes, etc.)

  2. each Agent gets to choose a Move.MoveView, but only if the current Pokemon is not locked into a multi-turn Move (such as Fly, Hyper Beam, etc.). If the Pokemon is locked into a multi-turn Move, that Move is automatically chosen. Otherwise, the Agent's selected Move.MoveView is coursely examined for legality, by checking that the pp of the selected move is > 0, and that the selected Move.MoveView atches as potentially legal move by the current Pokemon. The selected Move.MoveView is matched against the set of potential Move objects that the current Pokemon could have selected, and a more fine-grained legatily algorithm is applied later. Legal moves are defined here as one of the learned moved for the current Pokemon, a SwitchMove to swap out the current Pokemon for another (on your team), or StruggleMove.

  3. The move order is determined after both moves have been selected. If a Move is null, it will be assigned priority -1. The order moves are applied is determined using the following algorithm:
    1. The Move with the larger priority number goes first.
    2. The Pokemon with the larger current speed stat value goes first.
    3. The move order is chosen uniformly from the set {p1 -> p2, p2 -> p1} (i.e. 50/50 chance you go first)
    The NonVolatileStatus effect PARALYSIS reduces the current speed stat by 25\% here.

  4. Apply moves according to the move order. Before a Pokemon's Move is applied, the Team that Pokemon belongs to has some pre-move game logic applied. This pre-move game logic deals with the NonVolatileStatus effects SLEEP and FREEZE, which have a random chance of healing (once at the beginning of that Team's turn), and will wear off after a number of turns otherwise.

    After pre-move conditions are applied, a more fine grained "can the move even be applied" algorithm occurs. This algorithm checks if the current Pokemon is allowed to move, if the Move has pp remaining, and (if the Move is a SwitchMove), if the target Pokemon can be swapped. If the Move is not legal, or somehow fails this check, then that Pokemon will not make a move this turn.

    If the Move survives, then if the Pokemon is paralyzed or confused, there is a random chance that intead of making the selected move, the Pokemon is either paralyzed (and cannot go) or hurts itself (if its confused) instead of making the selected move. These random events occur here, and will either skip the Pokemon's turn (with self-inflicted damage in the case of confusion) or apply the intended move (in the case of a healthy Pokemon or one who passes the paralysis/confusion random chance). If the move ends up happening and was not set from a multi-turn move, then the pp of the Move is decremented.

  5. After both Pokemon have gone (or they were skipped), post turn logic is applied. This logic deals with NonVolatileStatus effects such as POISON, BURN, and TOXIC and some harmful non volatile status effects (called Flags) such as SEEDED. These side effects cause damage (and in the case of SEEDED cause some Pokemon to heal), and this damage exchance occurs at the end of every turn. Here is the order effects are applied:
    1. SEEDING occurs first, since there is a recipient for the damage caused. When a Pokemon is SEEDED, it loses 1/8th of is maximum (i.e. initial) HP, which is then used by the opponent's current Pokemon to heal that amount of HP.

    2. Any Pokemon that is burned, poisoned, toxic'd, or trapped is dealt damage. Trapping normally doesn't do damage on its own, but in gen-1 the only moves that can trap also cause damage at the end of every turn so I used the Flag of being TRAPPED as an indicator one of those post-turn damage-incurring moves was used (like Bind, Fire Spin, etc.). Being trapped causes a Pokemon to lose 1/16th of its max HP, being poisoned or burned costs 1/8th max HP, and being toxic'd costs N/16th of its max HP, where N is the number of turns that Pokemon has been toxic'd for. The value of N increases at the end of every turn until it hits 15, where it stays constant.

    3. Confusion/Trap counters are decreased at the end of every turn.
    4. If any Pokemon has fainted during this turn, that Team's Agent gets to choose a replacement Pokemon provided that there are any left to choose from.

    5. Flinched Flag is set to false for the current Pokemon.
    6. Light screen and Reflect counters are decreased for both Teams.
